review.title: Translating Neuralese
review.abstract: Several approaches have recently been proposed for learning decentralized deep multiagent policies that coordinate via a differentiable communication channel. While these policies are effective for many tasks, interpretation of their induced communication strategies has remained a challenge. Here we propose to interpret agents' messages by translating them. Unlike in typical machine translation problems, we have no parallel data to learn from. Instead we develop a translation model based on the insight that agent messages and natural language strings mean the same thing if they induce the same belief about the world in a listener. We present theoretical guarantees and empirical evidence that our approach preserves both the semantics and pragmatics of messages by ensuring that players communicating through a translation layer do not suffer a substantial loss in reward relative to players with a common language.

sections.text: While these strategies are effective for many tasks, interpreting their induced communication strategies remains a challenge. Here, we propose to interpret the messages of agents by translating them. Unlike typical machine translation problems, we do not have parallel data to learn from. Instead, we develop a translation model based on the recognition that agent messages and natural strands of language mean the same thing when they evoke the same belief in the world in the listener. We present theoretical guarantees and empirical evidence that our approach preserves both the semantics and pragmatics of messages by ensuring that players communicating across a translation layer do not suffer a significant loss of reward compared to players with players with a common language.

sections.heading: 2 Related work
sections.text: A variety of approaches to learning deep strategies with communication have been proposed essentially at the same time in the past year. We have broadly referred to these as "deep communication strategies"; concrete examples are Lazaridou et al. (2016b), Foerster et al. (2016) and Sukhbaatar et al. (2016). The political representation we use in this paper is similar to the latter two, although the general framework is agnostic to model low-level details and could be applied directly to other architectures. Analysis of communication strategies in all these papers is largely ad hoc, achieved through clusters of states from which similar messages are sent and attempts to manually assign semantic semantics to these clusters. sections.heading: 6 Belief and behavior
sections.text: It is therefore reasonable to ask whether this translation model of Section 5 can provide any guarantees about the effects of the translation on behaviour. To facilitate this analysis, we consider a simplified family of communication games with the structure shown in Figure 5. These games can be regarded as a subset of the family shown in Figure 3; and which consists of two steps: a listener makes an observation xa and sends a single message to a speaker who makes his own observation xb, and receives a reward. We stress that the results in this section concern the theoretical properties of idealised games and are presented intuitively.

sections.heading: 7.1 Tasks
sections.text: In the rest of the work, we evaluate the empirical behavior of our translation approach. Our evaluation takes into account two types of tasks: reference games and navigation games. In a reference game (e.g. Figure 6a), both players observe a pair of speakers. A speaker is assigned a speaker; he must communicate this goal to a listener who then performs a selection action corresponding to his belief in the true goal. In this thesis, we consider two variants of the reference game: a simple task for color naming and a more complex task with natural images of birds. For examples of human communication strategies for these tasks, we obtain the XKCD color dataset (McMahan and Stone, 2015; Monroe et al., 2016) and the Caltech Birds dataset (Welinder et al., 2010) with accom-panying Natural Language descriptions (Reed et al., 2016).

sections.heading: 7.2 Metrics
sections.text: A mechanism for understanding the behavior of a learned model should enable a human being to interpret his beliefs correctly and interact successfully with him. We use the available training data to develop simulated models of human decisions; by first showing that these models handle human judgments well, we can be sure that their use in evaluation correlates with human understanding.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: After introducing a translation criterion based on the listener's concurring beliefs about speaker states, we presented both theoretical and empirical evidence that this criterion surpasses a conventional machine translation approach in restoring the content of message vectors and facilitates collaboration between humans and scholars.While our assessment focused on understanding the behavior of deep communication policies, the framework proposed in this paper could be applied much more broadly. Any encoder decoder model (Sutskever et al., 2014) can be seen as a kind of communication game between the encoder and the decoder, so that we can analogously imagine calculating and translating "beliefs" generated by coding in order to explain what features of the input are transmitted. All of these approaches employ structured communication schemes with manually engineered messaging protocols; these are, in some sense, automatically interpretable, but at the cost of introducing considerable complexity into both training and inference. Our evaluation in this paper investigates communication strategies that arise in a number of different games, including reference games and an extended-horizon driving game.
